wikipedia_page.main:
Lieutenant-Colonel Sir Anthony Gadie T.D. (7 September 1868 – 24 August 1948) was an English businessman and Conservative Party politician from Bradford in West Yorkshire.
Gadie was self-made man. Born in a small cottage in Skipton, he became a builder and then an estate agent, a Lord Mayor of Bradford and a local councillor and alderman for 45 years. He served as an army officer in France during World War I and as a Member of Parliament (MP) in the 1920s, but is best known for his involvement with construction of the Scar House Reservoir.

link_mentions.page: List of MPs elected in the 1924 United Kingdom general election

response: * Sir Anthony Gadie (1868–1948) Military officer, Bradford Mayor and MP.

*Gadie, 0-6-0 saddle tank, Andrew Barclay no. 1866 of 1925. Bought new. The nameplates were transferred from the previous Gadie on arrival.  It was based at Scar Village and worked goods trains to Pateley Bridge. It was fitted with vacuum braking and an electric generator, and also worked Saturday passenger trains to Pateley Bridge. Sold 1934, and worked at Whifflet Foundry, Coatbridge. Lt. Colonel Anthony Gadie (later Sir Anthony) was a prominent person in the Waterworks Department from the 1890s until completion of Scar House Reservoir in 1936, and later chairman of the Waterworks Committee.
*Lieutenant-Colonel Anthony Gadie, T.D., J.P., Member of Parliament for Bradford Central, 1924–29. For political and public services in Bradford.
|1920-21 || Anthony Gadie ||Estate Agent  MP for Bradford Central, 1924
* Anthony Gadie (1868–1948), English businessman and politician

The memorial was unveiled on Saturday 1 July 1922, the sixth anniversary of the commencement of the First Battle of the Somme, in front of a crowd of 40,000 people, by Lt-Col Alderman Anthony Gadie (a former Lord Mayor of Bradford, and later MP for Bradford Central from 1924 to 1929).  It was dedicated by the Archdeacon of Bradford, William Stanton Jones (later Bishop of Sodor and Man).
